papers.title: AMMUS : A Survey of Transformer-based Pretrained Models in Natural Language Processing
papers.summary: This comprehensive survey paper explains various core concepts like pretraining, Pretraining methods, pretraining tasks, embeddings and downstream adaptation methods, presents a new taxonomy of T-PTLMs and gives brief overview of various benchmarks including both intrinsic and extrinsic.

papers.title: The SIGMORPHON 2022 Shared Task on Morpheme Segmentation
papers.authors: Khuyagbaatar Batsuren,Gábor Bella,Aryaman Arora,Viktor Martinovi'c,Kyle Gorman,Zdenvek vZabokrtsk'y,A. Ganbold,vS'arka Dohnalov'a,Magda vSevvc'ikov'a,Katevrina Pelegrinov'a,Fausto Giunchiglia,Ryan Cotterell,Ekaterina Vylomova

papers.title: MockingBERT: A Method for Retroactively Adding Resilience to NLP Models
papers.summary: A novel method of retroactively adding resilience to misspellings to transformer-based NLP models without the need for re-training of the original NLP model is proposed, which significantly reduces the cost needed to evaluate a model’s resilience to adversarial attacks.

papers.title: Advancing protein language models with linguistics: a roadmap for improved interpretability
papers.authors: Mai Ha Vu,R. Akbar,Philippe A. Robert,B. Swiatczak,V. Greiff,G. K. Sandve,Dag Trygve Tryslew Haug
papers.summary: It is argued that guidance drawn from linguistics, a field specialized in analytical rule extraction from natural language data, can aid with building more interpretable protein LMs that have learned relevant domain-specific rules.

papers.title: Demystifying Neural Language Models' Insensitivity to Word-Order
papers.summary: The insensitivity of natural language models to word-order is investigated by quantifying perturbations and analysing their effect on neural models’ performance on language understanding tasks in GLUE benchmark and it is found that neural language models — pretrained and non-pretrained Transformers, LSTMs, and Convolutional architectures — require local ordering more than the global ordering of tokens.

papers.title: Interpreting Character Embeddings With Perceptual Representations: The Case of Shape, Sound, and Color
papers.summary: This cross-lingual analysis shows that textual character representations correlate strongly with sound representations for languages using an alphabetic script, while shape correlates with featural scripts.

papers.title: Local Structure Matters Most: Perturbation Study in NLU
papers.summary: It is empirically shown that neural models, invariant of their inductive biases, pretraining scheme, or the choice of tokenization, mostly rely on the local structure of text to build understanding and make limited use of the global structure.

papers.title: Perceiver IO: A General Architecture for Structured Inputs & Outputs
papers.authors: Andrew Jaegle,Sebastian Borgeaud,Jean-Baptiste Alayrac,Carl Doersch,Catalin Ionescu,David Ding,Skanda Koppula,Andrew Brock,Evan Shelhamer,Olivier J. H'enaff,M. Botvinick,Andrew Zisserman,Oriol Vinyals,João Carreira
papers.summary: The primary focus of this work is generality, rather than speed on images, and Perceiver IO uses comparable FLOPs to attention-based image classiﬁcation models, especially for the more compact conﬂguration B pretrained on JFT.

papers.title: Hierarchical Transformers Are More Efficient Language Models
papers.authors: P. Nawrot,Szymon Tworkowski,Michal Tyrolski,Lukasz Kaiser,Yuhuai Wu,Christian Szegedy,H. Michalewski
papers.summary: Hourglass is a hierarchical Transformer language model that sets new state-of-the-art for Transformer models on the ImageNet32 generation task and improves language modeling efﬁciency on the widely studied enwik8 benchmark.

papers.title: Lifting the Curse of Multilinguality by Pre-training Modular Transformers
papers.authors: Jonas Pfeiffer,Naman Goyal,Xi Victoria Lin,Xian Li,James Cross,Sebastian Riedel,Mikel Artetxe
papers.summary: This work introduces language-specific modules of their Cross-lingual Modular models from the start, which allows them to grow the total capacity of the model, while keeping the total number of trainable parameters per language constant.

papers.title: NLP for Language Varieties of Italy: Challenges and the Path Forward
vTTS: visual-text to speech
papers.authors: Yoshifumi Nakano,Takaaki Saeki,Shinnosuke Takamichi,Katsuhito Sudoh,H. Saruwatari
papers.summary: Experimental results show that visual-text to speech is capable of generating speech with naturalness comparable to or better than a conventional TTS, it can transfer emphasis and emotion attributes in visual text to speech without additional labels and architectures, and it can synthesize more natural and intelligible speech from unseen and rare characters than conventional T TS.

papers.title: CMU’s Machine Translation System for IWSLT 2019
papers.summary: Block Multitask Learning (BMTL) is presented, a novel NMT architecture that predicts multiple targets of different granularities simulta- neously, removing the need to search for the optimal subword segmentation strategy.

papers.title: Multitask Learning For Different Subword Segmentations In Neural Machine Translation
papers.summary: Block Multitask Learning (BMTL), a novel NMT architecture that predicts multiple targets of different granularities simultaneously, removing the need to search for the optimal segmentation strategy, is presented.

papers.title: Neural Machine Translation with Imbalanced Classes
papers.summary: This work casts neural machine translation as a classification task in an autoregressive setting and analyzes the limitations of both classification and autoregression components, and investigates the effect of class imbalance on NMT.

papers.title: Joint Optimization of Tokenization and Downstream Model
papers.authors: Tatsuya Hiraoka,Sho Takase,Kei Uchiumi,Atsushi Keyaki,Naoaki Okazaki
papers.summary: Experimental results show that the proposed method improves the performance by determining appropriate tokenizations and can be used to explore the appropriate tokenization for an already trained model as post-processing.

papers.title: Domain Adaptation and Multi-Domain Adaptation for Neural Machine Translation: A Survey
papers.summary: This work surveys approaches to domain adaptation for NMT, particularly where a system may need to translate across multiple domains, and divides techniques into those revolving around data selection or generation, model architecture, parameter adaptation procedure, and inference procedure.

papers.title: DIRE and its Data: Neural Decompiled Variable Renamings with Respect to Software Class
papers.venue: ACM Transactions on Software Engineering and Methodology
papers.authors: Luke Dramko,Jeremy Lacomis,Pengcheng Yin,Edward J. Schwartz,Miltiadis Allamanis,Graham Neubig,Bogdan Vasilescu,Claire Le Goues
papers.summary: This work investigates how data provenance and the quality of training data affect performance, and how well, if at all, trained models generalize across software domains, and evaluates DIRE’s overall performance without respect to data quality.

papers.title: Intérêt des modèles de caractères pour la détection d’événements (The interest of character-level models for event detection)
papers.summary: D’intégrer des plongements de caractères, qui peuvent capturer des informations morphologiques et de forme sur les mots, à un modèle convolutif pour la détection d’événements, évaluons deux stratégies pour réaliser une telle intégration.

papers.title: An Ensemble of Pre-trained Transformer Models For Imbalanced Multiclass Malware Classification
papers.summary: The experiments demonstrate that the transformer model with one transformer block layer surpass the performance of the widely used base architecture, LSTM, and BERT or CANINE, the pre-trained transformer models, outperforms in classifying highly imbalanced malware families according to evaluation metrics: F1-score and AUC score.

papers.title: Checks and Strategies for Enabling Code-Switched Machine Translation
papers.summary: This work explores multilingual NMT models’ ability to handle code-switched text, and proposes checks to measure switching capability and investigates simple and effective data augmentation methods that can enhance an NMT model’s ability to support code- Switched text.

papers.title: Text Data Augmentation for Deep Learning
papers.summary: The major motifs of Data Augmentation are summarized into strengthening local decision boundaries, brute force training, causality and counterfactual examples, and the distinction between meaning and form.

papers.title: An Assessment of the Impact of OCR Noise on Language Models
papers.summary: It is found that OCR noise poses a significant obstacle to language modelling, with language models increasingly diverging from their noiseless targets as OCR quality lowers, and simpler models including PPMI and Word2Vec consistently outperform transformer-based models in this respect.

papers.title: One does not fit all! On the Complementarity of Vision Encoders for Vision and Language Tasks
papers.summary: This work evaluates whether the information stored within different VEs is complementary, i.e. if providing the model with features from multiple VEs can improve the performance on a target task, and suggests that diverse VEs complement each other, resulting in improved downstream V+L task performance.

papers.title: Multilingual Auxiliary Tasks Training: Bridging the Gap between Languages for Zero-Shot Transfer of Hate Speech Detection Models
papers.summary: It is proposed to train on multilingual auxiliary tasks – sentiment analysis, named entity recognition, and tasks relying on syntactic information – to improve zero-shot transfer of hate speech detection models across languages.

papers.title: Phone-ing it in: Towards Flexible Multi-Modal Language Model Training by Phonetic Representations of Data
papers.summary: Initial experiments using Swahili and Kinyarwanda data suggest the viability of the multi-modal approach for downstream Named Entity Recognition (NER) tasks, with models pre-trained on phone data showing an improvement of up to 6% F1-score above models that are trained from scratch.

papers.title: The Efficiency Misnomer
papers.authors: M. Dehghani,Anurag Arnab,L. Beyer,Ashish Vaswani,Yi Tay
papers.summary: It is demonstrated how incomplete reporting of cost indicators can lead to partial conclusions and a blurred or incomplete picture of the practical considerations of different models, and suggestions to improve reporting of efficiency metrics are presented.

papers.title: data2vec: A General Framework for Self-supervised Learning in Speech, Vision and Language
papers.authors: Alexei Baevski,Wei-Ning Hsu,Qiantong Xu,Arun Babu,Jiatao Gu,Michael Auli
papers.summary: Data2vec is a framework that uses the same learning method for either speech, NLP or computer vision to predict latent representations of the full input data based on a masked view of the input in a self-distillation setup using a standard Transformer architecture.

papers.title: A New Generation of Perspective API: Efficient Multilingual Character-level Transformers
papers.authors: Alyssa Lees,V. Tran,Yi Tay,Jeffrey Scott Sorensen,Jai Gupta,Donald Metzler,Lucy Vasserman
papers.summary: This paper presents the fundamentals behind the next version of the Perspective API from Google Jigsaw, and presents a single multilingual token-free Charformer model that is applicable across a range of languages, domains, and tasks.

papers.title: One Country, 700+ Languages: NLP Challenges for Underrepresented Languages and Dialects in Indonesia
papers.authors: A. F. Aji,Genta Indra Winata,Fajri Koto,Samuel Cahyawijaya,A. Romadhony,Rahmad Mahendra,Kemal Kurniawan,David Moeljadi,Radityo Eko Prasojo,Timothy Baldwin,Jey Han Lau,Sebastian Ruder
papers.summary: An overview of the current state of NLP research for Indonesia's 700+ languages is provided and general recommendations are provided to help develop NLP technology not only for languages of Indonesia but also other underrepresented languages.

papers.title: A Hierarchical N-Gram Framework for Zero-Shot Link Prediction
papers.authors: Mingchen Li,Junfan Chen,Samuel Mensah,Nikolaos Aletras,Xiulong Yang,Yang Ye
papers.summary: A Hierarchical N -gram framework for Z ero-S hot L ink P rediction (HNZSLP) that lever-ages character n-gram information for ZSLP and achieves state-of-the-art performance on two standard Z SLP datasets.

papers.title: Unifying Language Learning Paradigms
papers.authors: Yi Tay,M. Dehghani,V. Tran,Xavier García,Dara Bahri,Tal Schuster,Huaixiu Zheng,N. Houlsby,Donald Metzler
papers.summary: UL2 achieves SOTA performance on 50 well-established supervised NLP tasks ranging from language generation, language understanding, text classiﬁcation, question answering, commonsense reasoning, long text reasoning, structured knowledge grounding and information retrieval.

papers.title: UL2: Unifying Language Learning Paradigms
papers.authors: Yi Tay,M. Dehghani,V. Tran,Xavier García,Jason Wei,Xuezhi Wang,Hyung Won Chung,Dara Bahri,Tal Schuster,Huaixiu Zheng,Denny Zhou,N. Houlsby,Donald Metzler
papers.summary: By scaling the model up to 20B parameters, this paper achieves SOTA performance on 50 well-established supervised NLP tasks ranging from language generation, language understanding, text classiﬁcation, question answering, commonsense reasoning, long text reasoning, structured knowledge grounding and information retrieval.

papers.title: Layer or Representation Space: What Makes BERT-based Evaluation Metrics Robust?
papers.authors: Doan Nam Long Vu,N. Moosavi,Steffen Eger
papers.summary: It is shown that an embedding-based metric that has the highest correlation with human evaluations on a standard benchmark can have the lowest correlation if the amount of input noise or unknown tokens increases, and the highest robustness is achieved when using character-level embeddings, instead of token-based embeddments, from the first layer of the pretrained model.

papers.title: Word-level Morpheme segmentation using Transformer neural network
papers.summary: This paper presents the submission of team NUM DI to the SIGMORPHON 2022 Task on Morpheme Segmentation Part 1, word-level morpheme segmentation, and explores the transformer neural network approach to the shared task.

papers.title: TeDDi Sample: Text Data Diversity Sample for Language Comparison and Multilingual NLP
papers.authors: Steven Moran,C. Bentz,Ximena Gutierrez-Vasques,Olga Pelloni,T. Samardzic
papers.summary: The TeDDi sample is presented, a diversity sample of text data for language comparison and multilingual Natural Language Processing and its added value through for NLP and linguistic research is described.

papers.title: WikiNEuRal: Combined Neural and Knowledge-based Silver Data Creation for Multilingual NER
papers.authors: Simone Tedeschi,Valentino Maiorca,Niccolò Campolungo,Francesco Cecconi,R. Navigli
papers.summary: This paper exploits the texts of Wikipedia and introduces a new methodology based on the effective combination of knowledge-based approaches and neural models, together with a novel domain adaptation technique, to produce high-quality training corpora for NER.

papers.title: IWCLUL 2021 The Seventh International Workshop on Computational Linguistics of Uralic Languages
Evaluating Transferability of BERT Models on Uralic Languages
ID10M: Idiom Identification in 10 Languages
papers.summary: A novel multilingual Transformer-based system for the identiﬁcation and understanding of idioms and a high-quality automatically-created training dataset in 10 languages, along with a novel manually-curated evaluation benchmark are proposed.

papers.title: An ELECTRA Model for Latin Token Tagging Tasks
papers.summary: This report describes the KU Leuven / Brepols-CTLO submission to EvaLatin 2022, and presents the results of the current small Latin ELECTRA model, which will be expanded to a larger model in the future.

papers.title: Extended Overview of HIPE-2022: Named Entity Recognition and Linking in Multilingual Historical Documents
papers.authors: Maud Ehrmann,Matteo Romanello,Sven Najem-Meyer,Antoine Doucet,S. Clematide
papers.summary: An overview of the second edition of HIPE (Identifying Historical People, Places and other Entities), a shared task on named entity recognition and linking in multilingual historical documents, to gain new insights into the transferability of named entity processing approaches across languages, time periods, document types, and annotation tag sets.

papers.title: A Latent-Variable Model for Intrinsic Probing
papers.authors: Karolina Stańczak,Lucas Torroba Hennigen,Adina Williams,Ryan Cotterell,Isabelle Augenstein
papers.summary: This work proposes a novel latent-variable formulation for con-structing intrinsic probes and derives a tractable variational approximation to the log-likelihood and empirical evidence that pre-trained representations develop a cross-lingually entangled notion of morphosyntax.

papers.title: FiNER: Financial Numeric Entity Recognition for XBRL Tagging
papers.authors: Lefteris Loukas,Manos Fergadiotis,Ilias Chalkidis,Eirini Spyropoulou,Prodromos Malakasiotis,Ion Androutsopoulos,G. Paliouras
papers.summary: It is shown that subword fragmentation of numeric expressions harms BERT’s performance, allowing word-level BILSTMs to perform better, and two simple and effective solutions that replace numeric expressions with pseudo-tokens reflecting original token shapes and numeric magnitudes are proposed.

papers.title: UM6P-CS at SemEval-2022 Task 11: Enhancing Multilingual and Code-Mixed Complex Named Entity Recognition via Pseudo Labels using Multilingual Transformer
papers.authors: Abdellah El Mekki,Abdelkader El Mahdaouy,Mohammed Akallouch,Ismail Berrada,A. Khoumsi
papers.summary: This paper approaches the complex NER for multilingual and code-mixed queries, by relying on the contextualized representation provided by the multilingual Transformer XLM-RoBERTa, and incorporates a span classification loss to recognize named entities spans.

papers.title: Comparison of text preprocessing methods
papers.summary: The pros and cons of several common text preprocessing methods are discussed: removing formatting, tokenization, text normalization, handling punctuation, removing stopwords, stemming and lemmatization, n-gramming, and identifying multiword expressions.

papers.title: AdaSL: An Unsupervised Domain Adaptation framework for Arabic multi-dialectal Sequence Labeling
papers.authors: Abdellah El Mekki,Abdelkader El Mahdaouy,Ismail Berrada,A. Khoumsi

papers.title: KLASIFIKASI EMOSI PADA CUITAN DI TWITTER DENGAN PRINCIPAL COMPONENT ANALYSIS DAN SUPPORT VECTOR MACHINE
Cloud computing architecture for Tagging Arabic Text Using Hybrid Model
papers.summary: This paper presents and deploys a cloud computing architecture for Tagging Arabic text using a hybrid model, which will help reduce the efforts and cost and show an excellent accuracy rate in tagging an Arabic text and quickly respond.

papers.title: AI-Based Misogyny Detection from Arabic Levantine Twitter Tweets
papers.authors: Abdullah Y. Muaad,Prof. Jayappa(J) Hanumanthappa Davanagere,M. A. Al-antari,J. V. B. Benifa,C. Chola
papers.summary: An Arabic text recognition approach is presented for detecting misogyny from Arabic tweets using the Arabic Levantine Twitter Dataset for Misogynistic, and seems to be useful in providing practical smart solutions for detecting Arabic misogyny on social media.

papers.title: Arabic Document Classification: Performance Investigation of Preprocessing and Representation Techniques
papers.authors: Abdullah Y. Muaad,Hanumanthappa Jayappa Davanagere,D. Guru,J. V. B. Benifa,C. Chola,Hussain Alsalman,A. Gumaei,M. A. Al-antari
papers.summary: This work aims to identify the effectiveness of machine learning (ML) algorithms through preprocessing and representation techniques and shows that the classification performance strongly depends on the preprocessing technique, representation methods and classification technique, and the nature of datasets used.

papers.title: Modeling Target-Side Morphology in Neural Machine Translation: A Comparison of Strategies
papers.authors: Marion Weller-Di Marco,Matthias Huck,Alexander M. Fraser
papers.summary: This paper re-investigate two target-side linguistic processing techniques—a lemma-tag strategy (Tamchyna et al, 2017) and a linguistically informed word segmentation strategy (Huck et al., 2017b)—with one of the latest incarnations of neural architectures for machine translation, namely the Transformer model (Vaswani et al. 2017).

papers.title: How can NLP Help Revitalize Endangered Languages? A Case Study and Roadmap for the Cherokee Language
Quantifying Synthesis and Fusion and their Impact on Machine Translation
papers.authors: Arturo Oncevay,Duygu Ataman,N. V. Berkel,B. Haddow,Alexandra Birch,Johannes Bjerva

papers.title: DivEMT: Neural Machine Translation Post-Editing Effort Across Typologically Diverse Languages
papers.authors: Gabriele Sarti,Arianna Bisazza,Ana Guerberof Arenas,Antonio Toral
papers.summary: It is shown that post-editing is consistently faster than translation from scratch, however, the magnitude of productivity gains varies widely across systems and languages, highlighting major disparities in post-EDiting effectiveness for languages at different degrees of typological relatedness to English.

papers.title: Visual Cues and Error Correction for Translation Robustness
papers.summary: This paper focuses on three types of realistic noise that are commonly generated by humans and introduces the idea of visual context to improve translation robustness for noisy texts and describes a novel error correction training regime that can be used as an auxiliary task to further improvetranslation robustness.

papers.title: BERT-Defense: A Probabilistic Model Based on BERT to Combat Cognitively Inspired Orthographic Adversarial Attacks
papers.summary: This work shows that an untrained iterative approach which combines context-independent character-level information with context-dependent information from BERT’s masked language modeling can perform on par with human crowd-workers from Amazon Mechanical Turk supervised via 3-shot learning.

papers.title: Interpreting the Robustness of Neural NLP Models to Textual Perturbations
papers.summary: This work conducts extensive experiments with four prominent NLP models — TextRNN, BERT, RoBERTa and XLNet — over eight types of textual perturbations on three datasets, showing that a model which is better at identifying a perturbation becomes worse at ignoring such a perturgation at test time (lower robustness), providing empirical support for the hypothesis.

papers.title: Machine Translation Robustness to Natural Asemantic Variation
papers.summary: It is shown that NAV robustness can be transferred across languages and that synthetic perturbations can achieve some but not all of the ben-eﬁts of human-generated NAV data.

papers.title: Boosting Neural Machine Translation from Finnish to Northern Sámi with Rule-Based Backtranslation
papers.summary: A low-resource translation task from Finnish into Northern Sámi is considered, and it is found that the RBMT backtranslation outperforms NMT backtranslation clearly for the out-of-domain test set, but also slightly for the in-domain data, for which the N MT backtranslation model provided clearly better BLEU scores than the R BMT.

papers.title: Transformers for Low-Resource Languages: Is Féidir Linn!
papers.summary: It is demonstrated that choosing appropriate parameters leads to considerable performance improvements and the correct choice of subword model is shown to be the biggest driver of translation performance.

papers.title: On the Compatibility of Tokenizations Across Languages
papers.summary: It is shown that the compatibility measure proposed allows the system designer to create vocabularies across languages that are compatible – a desideratum that so far has been neglected in multilingual models.

papers.title: Many-to-English Machine Translation Tools, Data, and Pretrained Models
papers.summary: This work creates a multilingual neural machine translation model capable of translating from 500 source languages to English, readily downloadable and usable as a service, or as a parent model for transfer-learning to even lower-resource languages.

papers.title: Cross-Attention is All You Need: Adapting Pretrained Transformers for Machine Translation
papers.summary: It is revealed that fine-tuning only the cross-attention parameters is nearly as effective as fine- Tuning all parameters (i.e., the entire translation model) in terms of mitigation of catastrophic forgetting, the potential for zero-shot translation, and the ability to extend machine translation models to several new language pairs with reduced parameter storage overhead.

papers.title: On the Strengths of Cross-Attention in Pretrained Transformers for Machine Translation
papers.summary: It is found that, apart from the new language’s embeddings, only the cross-attention parameters need to be fine-tuned to obtain competitive BLEU performance.

papers.title: Diversifying Dialog Generation via Adaptive Label Smoothing
papers.summary: An Adaptive Label Smoothing (AdaLabel) approach that can adaptively estimate a target label distribution at each time step for different contexts, which outperforms various competitive baselines in producing diverse responses.

papers.title: BERT, mBERT, or BiBERT? A Study on Contextualized Embeddings for Neural Machine Translation
papers.summary: This paper demonstrates that simply using the output of a tailored and suitable bilingual pre-trained language model (dubbed BiBERT) as the input of the NMT encoder achieves state-of-the-art translation performance and proposes a stochastic layer selection approach and a dual-directional translation model to ensure the sufficient utilization of contextualized embeddings.

papers.title: Quasi Character-Level Transformers to Improve Neural Machine Translation on Small Datasets
papers.venue: 2021 Eighth International Conference on Social Network Analysis, Management and Security (SNAMS)
papers.summary: This work shows how this standard approach to subword segmentation might be counter-productive for small datasets or low-resource environments, where models trained with quasi character-level vocabularies seem to con-sistently outperform models with large subword vocABularies.

papers.title: BPE beyond Word Boundary: How NOT to use Multi Word Expressions in Neural Machine Translation
papers.summary: This work observes that naively extending BPE beyond word boundaries results in incoherent tokens which are themselves better represented as individual words, and finds that Pointwise Mutual Information (PMI) instead of frequency finds better MWEs (e.g., New\_York, Statue of Liberty, neither .

papers.title: IRB-NLP at SemEval-2022 Task 1: Exploring the Relationship Between Words and Their Semantic Representations
papers.summary: This paper gives a detailed overview of the systems that were designed for Definition Modeling and Reverse Dictionary tasks, and that achieved top scores on SemEval-2022 CODWOE challenge in several subtasks.

papers.title: Automatic Gloss-level Data Augmentation for Sign Language Translation
papers.authors: J. Jang,Han-Mu Park,Saim Shin,Suna Shin,Byung-Chen Yoon,G. Gweon
papers.summary: It is demonstrated that three different augmentation techniques used in existing Natural Language Processing (NLP) can be applied to sign language and an automatic data augmentation method which generates quality data by utilizing the Korean sign language gloss dictionary is proposed.

papers.title: Limitations and Challenges of Unsupervised Cross-lingual Pre-training
papers.summary: The results show that unsupervised cross-lingual methods are effective at inducing alignment even for distant languages and they benefit noticeably from subword information, but their effectiveness as pre-training models in machine translation is severely limited.

papers.title: HFT: High Frequency Tokens for Low-Resource NMT
papers.summary: This paper presents “High Frequency Tokenizer”, or HFT, a new language-independent subword segmentation algorithm that addresses low-frequency tokens in the training data and proposes a new metric to measure the frequency coverage of a tokenizer’s vocabulary, based on a frequency rank weighted average of the frequency values of its items.

papers.title: SeqTrans: Automatic Vulnerability Fix via Sequence to Sequence Learning
papers.authors: Jianlei Chi,YunHuan Qu,Ting Liu,Q. Zheng,Heng Yin
papers.summary: This paper provides a novel approach called SeqTrans to exploit historical vulnerability fixes to provide suggestions and automatically fix the source code, and proposes to leverage data flow dependencies to construct code sequences and fed them into the state-of-the-art transformer model.

papers.title: Frequency-Aware Contrastive Learning for Neural Machine Translation
papers.authors: Tong Zhang,Wei Ye,Baosong Yang,Long Zhang,Xingzhang Ren,Dayiheng Liu,Jinan Sun,Shikun Zhang,Haibo Zhang,Wen Zhao
papers.summary: A frequency-aware token-level contrastive learning method, in which the hidden state of each decoding step is pushed away from the counterparts of other target words in a soft contrastive way based on the corresponding word frequencies, which can not only significantly improve the translation quality but also enhance lexical diversity and optimize word representation space.

papers.title: IRB-NLP at SemEval-2022 Task 1: Exploring the Relationship Between Words and Their Semantic Representations
papers.summary: A detailed overview of the systems that are designed for Deﬁnition Modeling and Reverse Dictionary tasks, and that achieved top scores on SemEval-2022 CODWOE challenge in several subtasks are given.

papers.title: When does Parameter-Efficient Transfer Learning Work for Machine Translation?
papers.summary: It is shown that increas- 018 ing model size, but tuning only 0.03% of total parameters, can outperform tuning 100% of the 020 parameters of a smaller model 1 .

papers.title: Reinforcement Learning with Large Action Spaces for Neural Machine Translation
papers.summary: It is found that reducing the size of the vocabulary improves RL’s effectiveness and effectively reducing the dimension of the action space without changing the vocabulary also yields notable improvement as evaluated by BLEU, semantic similarity, and human evaluation.

papers.title: The VolcTrans System for WMT22 Multilingual Machine Translation Task
papers.authors: Xian Qian,Kai Hu,Jiaqiang Wang,Yifeng Liu,Xingyuan Pan,Jun Cao,Mingxuan Wang
papers.summary: The VolcTrans system is a transformer-based multilingual model trained on data from multiple sources including the public training set from the data track, NLLB data provided by Meta AI, self-collected parallel corpora, and pseudo bitext from back-translation to clean both bilingual and monolingual texts.

papers.title: String Processing and Information Retrieval: 27th International Symposium, SPIRE 2020, Orlando, FL, USA, October 13–15, 2020, Proceedings
papers.authors: A. Nishi,Yuto Nakashima,Shunsuke Inenaga,H. Bannai,M. Takeda
papers.summary: This paper proposes a new query that can be more appropriate in these collections of repetitive string collections, which is called contextual pattern matching and presents the first solution of this kind.

papers.title: Using Context to Help Predict Speaker's Emotions in Social Dialogue
Morphological segmentation method for Turkic language neural machine translation
papers.summary: A new morphological segmentation approach for Turkic languages based on the complete set of endings (CSE), which reduces the vocabulary volume of the source corpora and reduced the vocabulary size in NMT by more than a factor of two.

papers.title: Byte Pair Encoding is Suboptimal for Language Model Pretraining
papers.summary: Differences between BPE and unigram LM tokenization are analyzed, finding that the latter method recovers subword units that align more closely with morphology and avoids problems stemming from BPE’s greedy construction procedure.

papers.title: Practical Random Access to SLP-Compressed Texts
papers.authors: T. Gagie,I. Tomohiro,G. Manzini,G. Navarro,H. Sakamoto,Louisa Seelbach Benkner,Yoshimasa Takabatake
papers.summary: A new encoding of grammars that is about as small as the practical state of the art but with significantly faster queries and the possibility of supporting fast random access is given.

papers.title: IIITT at CASE 2021 Task 1: Leveraging Pretrained Language Models for Multilingual Protest Detection
papers.authors: Pawan Kalyan,D.Ramohan Reddy,Adeep Hande,R. Priyadharshini,Ratnasingam Sakuntharaj,Bharathi Raja Chakravarthi
papers.summary: This paper demonstrates its work on the sentence classification subtask of multilingual protest detection in CASE@ACL-IJCNLP 2021 by employing various multilingual pre-trained transformer models to classify if any sentence contains information about an event that has transpired or not.

papers.title: Optimizing Word Alignments with Better Subword Tokenization
papers.summary: This paper thoroughly study how this preprocessing step interacts with the word alignment task and proposes several tokenization strategies to obtain well-segmented parallel corpora and improves baseline word-based alignment models for six language pairs.

papers.title: No Features Needed: Using BPE Sequence Embeddings for Web Log Anomaly Detection
How Effective is Byte Pair Encoding for Out-Of-Vocabulary Words in Neural Machine Translation?
papers.summary: This paper analyzes the translation quality of OOV words based on word type, number of segments, cross-attention weights, and the frequency of segment n-grams in the training data and highlights the slightly higher effectiveness of BPE in translating OOV Words for special cases, such as named-entities and when the languages involved are linguistically close to each other.

papers.title: ARC-NLP at CheckThat!-2022: Contradiction for Harmful Tweet Detection
papers.summary: The winning solution for Task-1C, harmful tweet detection in Turkish, using ARC-NLP-contra is presented, which is a contradiction check approach by using the idea that harmful tweets contradict with the real-life facts in the scope of COVID-19 pandemic.

papers.title: State-of-the-art generalisation research in NLP: a taxonomy and review
papers.authors: D. Hupkes,Mario Giulianelli,Verna Dankers,Mikel Artetxe,Yanai Elazar,Tiago Pimentel,Christos Christodoulopoulos,Karim Lasri,Naomi Saphra,Arabella J. Sinclair,Dennis Ulmer,Florian Schottmann,Khuyagbaatar Batsuren,Kaiser Sun,Koustuv Sinha,Leila Khalatbari,Maria Ryskina,Rita Frieske,Ryan Cotterell,Zhijing Jin
papers.summary: A taxonomy for characterising and understanding generalisation research in NLP is presented, a taxonomy is used to present a comprehensive map of published generalisation studies, and recommendations for which areas might deserve attention in the future are made.

papers.title: Text normalization for endangered languages: the case of Ligurian
papers.summary: It is shown that, in spite of the small amounts of data available, a compact transformer-based model can be trained to achieve very low error rates by the use of backtranslation and appropriate tokenization.

papers.title: Pronunciation-aware unique character encoding for RNN Transducer-based Mandarin speech recognition
papers.summary: A novel pronunciation-aware unique character encoding is proposed for building E2E RNN-T-based Mandarin ASR systems that can overcome the homophone problem while utilizing the pronunciation information for extracting modeling units.

papers.title: The Risks of Machine Learning Systems
papers.summary: MLR unifies the risks that are commonly discussed in the ethical AI community with system-level risks, paving the way for holistic risk assessments of ML systems.

papers.title: Word-order Typology in Multilingual BERT: A Case Study in Subordinate-Clause Detection
Text Generation with Text-Editing Models
papers.authors: Eric Malmi,Yue Dong,Jonathan Mallinson,A. Chuklin,Jakub Adamek,Daniil Mirylenka,Felix Stahlberg,Sebastian Krause,Shankar Kumar,Aliaksei Severyn
papers.summary: This tutorial provides a comprehensive overview of the text-edit based models and current state-of-the-art approaches analyzing their pros and cons.

papers.title: Evolving Label Usage within Generation Z when Self-Describing Sexual Orientation
Sensitive Data Detection with High-Throughput Neural Network Models for Financial Institutions
papers.summary: The experimental results show that the CNN model is simple yet effective with respect to accuracy and throughput and thus, is the most suitable candidate model to be deployed in the production environment(s), and several lessons learned on data limitations, data labelling and the intrinsic overlap of data entities are provided.

papers.title: FETD2: A Framework for Enabling Textual Data Denoising via Robust Contextual Embeddings
Type- and Token-based Word Embeddings in the Digital Humanities
papers.summary: The main goal of this contribution is to make an evidence-based argument that research on static embeddings should be continued not only because it needs less computing power and smaller corpora, but also because for this specific set of applications their performance is on par with that of dynamicembeddings.

papers.title: Differential Evaluation: a Qualitative Analysis of Natural Language Processing System Behavior Based Upon Data Resistance to Processing
papers.authors: L. Gianola,Hicham El Boukkouri,Cyril Grouin,T. Lavergne,P. Paroubek,Pierre Zweigenbaum
papers.summary: The notion of differential evaluation is introduced which effectively defines a pragmatic partition of instances into gradually more difficult bins by leveraging the predictions made by a set of systems.

papers.title: Easy-to-use Combination of POS and BERT Model for Domain-Specific and Misspelled Terms
papers.summary: BERT-POS, a simple method for encoding syntax into BERT embeddings without re-training or finetuning data, based on Part-Of-Speech (POS), works at the preprocessing level and relies on POS tagging sentences.

papers.title: UniParma at SemEval-2021 Task 5: Toxic Spans Detection Using CharacterBERT and Bag-of-Words Model
papers.summary: A state-of-the-art pre-trained language model (CharacterBERT), fed into the well-known BERT architecture, is used to extract features based on the word characters and improves upon that by making sure that some frequently used toxic words get labeled accordingly.

papers.title: IIITT@LT-EDI-EACL2021-Hope Speech Detection: There is always hope in Transformers
papers.authors: Karthik Puranik,Adeep Hande,R. Priyadharshini,Sajeetha Thavareesan,Bharathi Raja Chakravarthi
papers.summary: This paper portrays the work for the Shared Task on Hope Speech Detection for Equality, Diversity, and Inclusion at LT-EDI 2021- EACL 2021 and works with several transformer-based models to classify social media comments as hope speech or not hope speech in English, Malayalam, and Tamil languages.

papers.title: CodemixedNLP: An Extensible and Open NLP Toolkit for Code-Mixing
papers.authors: Sai Muralidhar Jayanthi,Kavya Nerella,Khyathi Raghavi Chandu,A. Black
papers.summary: CodemixedNLP is an open-source library that consists of tools to develop and benchmark versatile model architectures that are tailored for mixed texts, methods to expand training sets, techniques to quantify mixing styles, and fine-tuned state-of-the-art models for 7 tasks in Hinglish.

papers.title: Combining formal and machine learning techniques for the generation of JML specifications
papers.summary: It is shown how to generate JML annotations using a combination of 1) automatic generation of minimal predicates, 2) Natural Language Processing (NLP) based predicates generator, and 3) manual refinement and correction, to instrument and enhance code and documentation.

papers.title: Character-Level Syntax Infusion in Pre-Trained Models for Chinese Semantic Role Labeling
papers.summary: The Character-Level Syntax-Infused network for Chinese SRL is proposed, which effectively incorporates the syntactic information between Chinese characters into pre-trained models and achieves state-of-the-art results.

papers.title: Benchmarking Multi-Task Learning for Sentiment Analysis and Offensive Language Identification in Under-Resourced Dravidian Languages
papers.authors: Adeep Hande,Siddhanth U Hegde,R. Priyadharshini,R. Ponnusamy,P. Kumaresan,Sajeetha Thavareesan,Bharathi Raja Chakravarthi
papers.summary: Analysis of fine-tuned models indicates the preference of multi-task learning over single- task learning resulting in a higher weighted F1-score on all three languages, including Kannada, Malayalam and Tamil.

papers.title: CancerBERT: a BERT model for Extracting Breast Cancer Phenotypes from Electronic Health Records
papers.authors: Sicheng Zhou,Liwei Wang,Nan Wang,Hongfang Liu,Rui Zhang
papers.summary: The developed and evaluated cancer domain pre-trained CancerBERT models that are able to extract comprehensive collections of breast cancer related phenotypes and validated that using customized vocabulary may further improve the performances of domain specific BERT models in clinical NLP tasks.

papers.title: Imposing Relation Structure in Language-Model Embeddings Using Contrastive Learning
papers.authors: Christos Theodoropoulos,J. Henderson,Andrei Catalin Coman,Marie-Francine Moens
papers.summary: A novel contrastive learning framework is proposed that trains sentence embeddings to encode the relations in a graph structure to achieve state-of-the-art results on the relation extraction task using only a simple KNN classifier.

papers.title: BERT Cannot Align Characters
papers.summary: It is shown that the closer two languages are, the better BERT can align them on the character level, and the similarity matrices for natural languages show weaker relations the further apart two language are.

papers.title: Low Frequency Names Exhibit Bias and Overfitting in Contextualizing Language Models
papers.summary: It is found that infrequent names are more self-similar across contexts, indicating that models rely on less context-informed representations of uncommon and minority names which are overfit to a lower number of observed contexts.

papers.title: Switch Point biased Self-Training: Re-purposing Pretrained Models for Code-Switching
papers.authors: P. Chopra,Sai Krishna Rallabandi,A. Black,Khyathi Raghavi Chandu
papers.summary: This work proposes a self training method to repurpose the existing pretrained models using a switch-point bias by leveraging unannotated data and demonstrates that this approach performs well on both sequence labeling tasks.

papers.title: Using Distributional Principles for the Semantic Study of Contextual Language Models
papers.summary: This article focuses on semantic similarity properties for English by exploiting the distributional principle of substitution as a probing mechanism in the controlled context of SemCor and WordNet paradigmatic relations and proposes to adapt the same method to a more open setting for characterizing the differences between static and contextual language models.

papers.title: Transferring BERT-like Transformers' Knowledge for Authorship Verification
papers.authors: Andrei Manolache,Florin Brad,Elena Burceanu,Antonio Bărbălău,R. Ionescu,M. Popescu
papers.summary: This work studies the effectiveness of several BERT-like transformers for the task of authorship verification and shows that those splits can enhance the models’ capability to transfer knowledge over a new, significantly different dataset.

papers.title: Gated Character-aware Convolutional Neural Network for Effective Automated Essay Scoring
papers.authors: Huanyu Bai,Zhilin Huang,Anran Hao,S. C. Hui
papers.summary: The experimental results show that the proposed GCCNN model outperforms the baseline deep learning models and the qualitative analysis demonstrates the importance of character-level information for tackling the out-of-vocabulary problem in grading essays.

papers.title: A Survey of Pretrained Language Models Based Text Generation
papers.authors: Junyi Li,Tianyi Tang,Wayne Xin Zhao,J. Nie,Ji-rong Wen
papers.summary: This survey presents the recent advances achieved in the topic of PLMs for text generation and introduces three key points of applying PLMs to text generation: how to encode the input data as representations preserving input semantics which can be fused into PLMs.

papers.title: RoCBert: Robust Chinese Bert with Multimodal Contrastive Pretraining
papers.authors: Hui Su,Weiwei Shi,Xiaoyu Shen,Zhou Xiao,Tuo Ji,Jiarui Fang,Jie Zhou
papers.summary: RoCBert is a pretrained Chinese Bert that is robust to various forms of adversarial attacks like word perturbation, synonyms, typos, etc, and is pretrained with the contrastive learning objective which maximizes the label consistency under different synthesized adversarial examples.

papers.title: Design principles of an open-source language modeling microservice package for AAC text-entry applications
papers.summary: MzoLM, an open-source language model microservice package intended for use in AAC text-entry applications, is presented, with a particular focus on the design principles of the library.

papers.title: Building Static Embeddings from Contextual Ones: Is It Useful for Building Distributional Thesauri?
papers.summary: This article proposes a new method for building word or type-level embeddings from contextual models that combines the generalization and the aggregation of token representations and evaluates it for a large set of English nouns from the perspective of the building of distributional thesauri for extracting semantic similarity relations.

papers.title: DeepREF: A Framework for Optimized Deep Learning-based Relation Classification
papers.authors: Igor Nascimento,Rinaldo Lima,Adrian-Gabriel Chifu,B. Espinasse,S. Fournier
papers.summary: A new open and optimizable framework, called DeepREF, is proposed, which is inspired by the OpenNRE and REflex existing frameworks, and allows the employment of various deep learning models, to optimize their use, to identify the best inputs and to get better results with each data set for RE.

papers.title: Décontextualiser des plongements contextuels pour construire des thésaurus distributionnels (Decontextualizing contextual embeddings for building distributional thesauri )
AMMU - A Survey of Transformer-based Biomedical Pretrained Language Models
papers.summary: This survey discusses core concepts of transformer-based PLMs like pretraining methods, pretraining tasks, fine-tuning methods, and various embedding types specific to biomedical domain, and introduces a taxonomy for transformerbased BPLMs.

papers.title: DravidianCodeMix: sentiment analysis and offensive language identification dataset for Dravidian languages in code-mixed text
papers.authors: Bharathi Raja Chakravarthi,R. Priyadharshini,V. Muralidaran,Navya Jose,Shardul Suryawanshi,E. Sherly,John P. McCrae
papers.summary: A multilingual, manually annotated dataset for three under-resourced Dravidian languages generated from social media comments, which contains all types of code-mixing phenomena since it comprises user-generated content from a multilingual country.

papers.title: Automatic Classification of Cancer Pathology Reports: A Systematic Review
papers.authors: Thiago Santos,Amara Tariq,J. Gichoya,H. Trivedi,I. Banerjee
papers.summary: This systematic review identifies the NLP systems for classifying pathology reports published between the years of 2010 and 2021 and benchmarked the systems based on methodology, complexity of the prediction task and core types of NLP models.

papers.title: Towards improving the robustness of sequential labeling models against typographical adversarial examples using triplet loss
papers.summary: Experiments show that the proposed adversarial training framework provides better resistance against adversarial examples on all tasks, and can further improve the model’s robustness on the chunking task by including a triplet loss constraint.

papers.title: The EMory BrEast imaging Dataset (EMBED): A Racially Diverse, Granular Dataset of 3.5M Screening and Diagnostic Mammograms
papers.authors: J. Jeong,B. Vey,A. Bhimireddy,Thomas Kim,Thiago Santos,R. Correa,Raman Dutt,M. Mosunjac,G. Oprea-Ilies,Geoffrey Smith,Min-Jae Woo,Christopher R. McAdams,M. Newell,I. Banerjee,J. Gichoya,H. Trivedi
papers.summary: The EMory BrEast imaging Dataset (EMBED) addresses gaps by providing 3650,000 2D and DBT screening and diagnostic mammograms for 116,000 women divided equally between White and African American patients.

papers.title: An open-source natural language processing toolkit to support software development: addressing automatic bug detection, code summarisation and code search
papers.authors: Cristian Robledo,Francesca Sallicati,G. de Chalendar,Marcos Fernández,Pablo de Castro,Eduardo Martín,Javier Gutiérrez,Yannis Bouachera
papers.summary: The paper focuses on the NLP tools developed and integrated in the Persistent Knowledge Monitor, namely the deep learning models developed to perform variable misuse, code summarisation and semantic parsing.

papers.title: Imputing Out-of-Vocabulary Embeddings with LOVE Makes LanguageModels Robust with Little Cost
papers.summary: A simple contrastive learning framework, LOVE, which extends the word representation of an existing pre-trained language model and makes it robust to OOV with few additional parameters, and can be used in a plug-and-play fashion with FastText and BERT, where it significantly improves their robustness.

papers.title: Signal in Noise: Exploring Meaning Encoded in Random Character Sequences with Character-Aware Language Models
papers.authors: Mark Chu,Bhargav Srinivasa Desikan,E. Nadler,Ruggerio L. Sardo,Elise Darragh-Ford,Douglas Guilbeault
papers.summary: It is proposed that n-grams composed of random character sequences, or garble, provide a novel context for studying word meaning both within and beyond extant language, and it is shown that meaning and primitive information are intrinsically linked.

papers.title: CancerBERT: a cancer domain-specific language model for extracting breast cancer phenotypes from electronic health records
papers.authors: Sicheng Zhou,Nan Wang,Liwei Wang,Hongfang Liu,Rui Zhang
papers.summary: The results validated that using customized vocabulary may further improve the performances of domain specific BERT models in clinical NLP tasks and developed and evaluated CancerBERT models to extract the cancer phenotypes in clinical notes and pathology reports.

papers.title: Mixed-Phoneme BERT: Improving BERT with Mixed Phoneme and Sup-Phoneme Representations for Text to Speech
papers.authors: Guangyan Zhang,Kaitao Song,Xu Tan,Daxin Tan,Yuzi Yan,Yanqing Liu,G. Wang,Wei Zhou,Tao Qin,Tan Lee,Sheng Zhao
papers.summary: The proposed Mixed-Phoneme BERT is a novel variant of the BERT model that uses mixed phoneme and sup-phoneme representations to enhance the learning capability and achieves 3 × inference speedup and similar voice quality to the previous TTS pre-trained model PnG BERT.

papers.title: CharacterBERT and Self-Teaching for Improving the Robustness of Dense Retrievers on Queries with Typos
papers.summary: This paper shows that a small character level perturbation in queries (as caused by typos) highly impacts the effectiveness of dense retrievers, and develops dense retriever methods that are robust to such queries with typos, while still being as performant as previous methods on queries without typos.

papers.title: Data Augmentation for Biomedical Factoid Question Answering
papers.summary: It is shown that DA can lead to very significant performance gains, even when using large pre-trained Transformers, contributing to a broader discussion of if/when DA benefits large pre -trained models.

papers.title: Decorate the Examples: A Simple Method of Prompt Design for Biomedical Relation Extraction
papers.summary: This paper presents a simple yet effective method to systematically generate comprehensive prompts that reformulate the relation extraction task as a cloze-test task under a simple prompt formulation, and finds prompt-based learning requires fewer training examples to make reasonable predictions.

papers.title: Multi-task learning in under-resourced Dravidian languages
papers.venue: Journal of Data, Information and Management
papers.authors: Adeep Hande,Siddhanth U Hegde,Bharathi Raja Chakravarthi
papers.summary: Analysis of fine-tuned models indicates the preference of multi-task learning over single task learning resulting in a higher weighted F1 score on all three languages, and this framework is applicable to other sequence classification problems irrespective to the size of the datasets.

papers.title: A review on Natural Language Processing Models for COVID-19 research
papers.summary: A range of transformer-based biomedical pretrained language models are evaluated using the BLURB benchmark and the novel T-BPLM BioLinkBERT gives groundbreaking results by incorporating document link knowledge and hyperlinking into its pretraining.

papers.title: Cross-lingual Approaches for the Detection of Adverse Drug Reactions in German from a Patient’s Perspective
papers.authors: Lisa Raithel,Philippe E. Thomas,Roland Roller,Oliver Sapina,Sebastian Moller,Pierre Zweigenbaum
papers.summary: This work presents the first corpus for German Adverse Drug Reaction (ADR) detection in patient-generated content, consisting of 4,169 binary annotated documents from a German patient forum, and provides preliminary experiments for binary classification using different methods of zero- and few-shot learning based on a multi-lingual model.

papers.title: Medical terminology-based computing system: a lightweight post-processing solution for out-of-vocabulary multi-word terms
papers.summary: This study presents MedTCS—a lightweight, post-processing module—to simplify hybridized or compound terms into regular words using medical nomenclature and demonstrates that the proposed module enables the word embedding models to generate vectors of out-of-vocabulary words effectively.

papers.title: IMSE: interaction information attention and molecular structure based drug drug interaction extraction
papers.summary: A model that leverages state of the art transformer architecture in conjunction with multiple features can bolster the performances of drug drug interation tasks in the biomedical domain and would be helpful in identification of potential adverse drug reactions.

papers.title: Survey of NLP in Pharmacology: Methodology, Tasks, Resources, Knowledge, and Tools
papers.authors: D. Trajanov,Vangel Trajkovski,Makedonka Dimitrieva,Jovana Dobreva,Milos Jovanovik,Matej Klemen,Alevs vZagar,Marko Robnik-vSikonja
papers.summary: This work splits the coverage into categories to survey modern NLP methodology, commonly addressed tasks, relevant textual data, knowledge bases, and useful programming libraries, and presents a comprehensive overview of the area.

papers.title: On the State of the Art in Authorship Attribution and Authorship Verification
papers.summary: It is shown that through the application of hard-negative mining, AV methods are competitive alternatives to AA methods, and on the two AA datasets with the greatest number of words per author, BERT-based models perform best.

papers.title: Enriching Biomedical Knowledge for Low-resource Language Through Translation
papers.authors: Long Phan,Tai Dang,Hieu Tran,Vy Phan,Lam D. Chau,Trieu H. Trinh
papers.summary: A state-of-theart translation model in English-Vietnamese is made use to translate and produce both pretrained as well as supervised data in the biomedical domains, and ViPubmedT5, a pretrained Encoder-Decoder Transformer model trained on 20 million translated abstracts from the high-quality public PubMed corpus is introduced.

papers.title: Neural Machine Translation
papers.summary: A comprehensive treatment of the topic, ranging from introduction to neural networks, computation graphs, description of the currently dominant attentional sequence-to-sequence model, recent refinements, alternative architectures and challenges.

papers.title: Lattice-Based Transformer Encoder for Neural Machine Translation
papers.authors: Fengshun Xiao,Jiangtong Li,Zhao Hai,Rui Wang,Kehai Chen
papers.summary: This work proposes lattice-based encoders to explore effective word or subword representation in an automatic way during training and proposes two methods: 1) lattice positional encoding and 2) lattICE-aware self-attention to further improve translation performance.

papers.title: Character n-gram Embeddings to Improve RNN Language Models
papers.summary: A novel Recurrent Neural Network (RNN) language model that takes advantage of character information based on research in the field of word embedding construction and combines them with ordinary word embeddings is proposed.

papers.title: Latent Part-of-Speech Sequences for Neural Machine Translation
papers.authors: Xuewen Yang,Yingru Liu,Dongliang Xie,Xin Wang,Niranjan Balasubramanian
papers.summary: A new latent variable model, LaSyn, is introduced that captures the co-dependence between syntax and semantics, while allowing for effective and efficient inference over the latent space.

papers.title: Trends and Advances in Neural Machine Translation
papers.venue: 2020 IEEE International Conference for Innovation in Technology (INOCON)
papers.summary: This paper breaks down different models, approaches, inception, principle development, and structures utilized in NMT to discover a productive strategy to make a translation system and identifying the advances and imperfections of the equivalent.

papers.title: Mixed-Level Neural Machine Translation
papers.summary: A novel heterogeneous translation unit system, considering linguistic characteristics of the synthetic Russian language and the analytic Vietnamese language is proposed, which improves over the existing best homogeneous Russian-Vietnamese translation system by 1.17 BLEU.

papers.title: Neural Machine Translation: A Review of Methods, Resources, and Tools
papers.authors: Zhixing Tan,Shuo Wang,Zonghan Yang,Gang Chen,Xuancheng Huang,Maosong Sun,Yang Liu
papers.summary: A broad review of the methods for NMT is provided and focus on methods relating to architectures, decoding, and data augmentation, with a discussion of possible future research directions.

papers.title: Sub-Subword N-Gram Features for Subword-Level Neural Machine Translation
papers.summary: A novel approach that combines subword-level segmentation with character-level information in the form of character n-gram features to construct embedding matrices and softmax output projections for a standard encoderdecoder model that increases the vocabulary size for small training datasets without reducing translation quality.

papers.title: Byte-based Multilingual NMT for Endangered Languages
papers.summary: This work proposes a byte-based multilingual neural machine translation system (BMNMT), which consistently and significantly outperforms subword/word-based baselines on twelve language pairs up to +18.5 BLEU points, an 840% relative improvement.

papers.title: Learning Multiscale Transformer Models for Sequence Generation
papers.authors: Bei Li,Tong Zheng,Yi Jing,Chengbo Jiao,Tong Xiao,Jingbo Zhu
papers.summary: This work built a multiscale Transformer model by establishing relationships among scales based on word-boundary information and phrase-level prior knowledge and yielded consistent performance gains over the strong baseline on several test sets without sacrificing the efficiency.

papers.title: SIT at MixMT 2022: Fluent Translation Built on Giant Pre-trained Models
papers.authors: Abdul Rafae Khan,Hrishikesh Kanade,Girish Amar Budhrani,Preet Jhanglani,Jia Xu
papers.summary: This paper describes the Stevens Institute of Technology’s submission for the WMT 2022 Shared Task: Code-mixed Machine Translation (MixMT), which consisted of two subtasks, subtask 1 Hindi/English to Hinglish and subtask 2 Hinglit to English translation.

papers.title: Exploring Phoneme-Level Speech Representations for End-to-End Speech Translation
papers.summary: This work shows that a naive method to create compressed phoneme-like speech representations is far more effective and efficient for translation than traditional frame-level speech features.

papers.title: Comparison between NMT and PBSMT Performance for Translating Noisy User-Generated Content
papers.authors: José Carlos Rosales Núñez,Djamé Seddah,Guillaume Wisniewski
papers.summary: It is shown that, contrary to what could be expected, PBSMT outperforms NMT when translating non-canonical inputs, and suggests new avenue for improving NMT models.

papers.title: Neural Machine Translation: A Review and Survey
papers.summary: This work traces back the origins of modern NMT architectures to word and sentence embeddings and earlier examples of the encoder-decoder network family and concludes with a survey of recent trends in the field.

papers.title: Neural Machine Translation: A Review
papers.summary: This work traces back the origins of modern NMT architectures to word and sentence embeddings and earlier examples of the encoder-decoder network family and concludes with a survey of recent trends in the field.

papers.title: Adversarial Subword Regularization for Robust Neural Machine Translation
papers.summary: This paper presents adversarial subword regularization (ADVSR) to study whether gradient signals during training can be a substitute criterion for exposing diverse subword segmentations and experimentally shows that the model-based adversarial samples effectively encourage NMT models to be less sensitive to segmentation errors and improve the performance of N MT models in low-resource and out-domain datasets.

papers.title: Transfer learning and subword sampling for asymmetric-resource one-to-many neural translation
papers.summary: This work reviews approaches for improving neural machine translation for low-resource languages in the context of an asymmetric-resource one-to-many translation task, in which the pair of target languages are related, with one being a very low- resource and the other a higher-resource language.

papers.title: The Roles of Language Models and Hierarchical Models in Neural Sequence-to-Sequence Prediction
papers.summary: It is shown how traditional symbolic statistical machine translation models can still improve neural machine translation while reducing the risk of common pathologies of NMT such as hallucinations and neologisms.

papers.title: Optimizing Word Segmentation for Downstream Task
papers.authors: Tatsuya Hiraoka,Sho Takase,Kei Uchiumi,Atsushi Keyaki,Naoaki Okazaki
papers.summary: The proposed method, optimizing tokenization (OpTok), is trained to assign a high probability to such appropriate tokenization based on the downstream task loss, and can be used for any downstream task which uses a vector representation of a sentence such as text classification.

papers.title: VOLT: Improving Vocabularization via Optimal Transport for Machine Translation
papers.authors: Jingjing Xu,Hao Zhou,Chun Gan,Zaixiang Zheng,Lei Li
papers.summary: An exciting relation between an information-theoretic feature and BLEU scores is found and it is found that VOLT beats widely-used vocabularies on diverse scenarios, and one advantage of VOLT lies in its low resource consumption.

papers.title: Vocabulary Learning via Optimal Transport for Neural Machine Translation
papers.authors: Jingjing Xu,Hao Zhou,Chun Gan,Zaixiang Zheng,Lei Li
papers.summary: This paper proposes VOLT, a simple and efficient solution without trial training that beats widely-used vocabularies in diverse scenarios, including WMT-14 English-German translation, TED bilingual translation, and TED multilingual translation.

papers.title: Translation Mechanism of Neural Machine Algorithm for Online English Resources
papers.summary: This paper proposes a framework that integrates vocabulary alignment structure for neural machine translation at the vocabulary level and uses the word alignment structure of statistical machine translation as the external vocabulary alignment information and introduces it into the decoding step of Neural machine translation.

papers.title: You should evaluate your language model on marginal likelihood over tokenisations
papers.summary: It is argued that language models should be evaluated on their marginal likelihood over tokenisations, and it is shown that the marginal perplexity can be significantly better than the one best, especially on out-of-domain data.

papers.title: Clustering Monolingual Vocabularies to Improve Cross-Lingual Generalization
papers.summary: This work explores the idea of learning multilingual language models based on clustering of monolingual segments and shows significant improvements over standard multilingual segmentation and training across nine languages on a question answering task, both in a small model regime and for a model of the size of BERT-base.

papers.title: How Good is Your Tokenizer? On the Monolingual Performance of Multilingual Language Models
papers.authors: Phillip Rust,Jonas Pfeiffer,Ivan Vulic,Sebastian Ruder,Iryna Gurevych
papers.summary: It is found that replacing the original multilingual tokenizer with the specialized monolingual tokenizer improves the downstream performance of the multilingual model for almost every task and language.

papers.title: BanglaBERT: Combating Embedding Barrier in Multilingual Models for Low-Resource Language Understanding
papers.authors: Abhik Bhattacharjee,Tahmid Hasan,Kazi Samin,Md. Saiful Islam,M. S. Rahman,Anindya Iqbal,Rifat Shahriyar
papers.summary: The Embedding Barrier is introduced, a phenomenon that limits the monolingual performance of multilingual models on low-resource languages having unique typologies and a straightforward solution by transcribing languages to a common script is proposed, which can effectively improve the performance of a multilingual model for the Bangla language.

papers.title: XTREME-R: Towards More Challenging and Nuanced Multilingual Evaluation
papers.authors: Sebastian Ruder,Noah Constant,Jan A. Botha,Aditya Siddhant,Orhan Firat,Jinlan Fu,Pengfei Liu,Junjie Hu,Graham Neubig,Melvin Johnson
papers.summary: This paper analyzes the current state of cross-lingual transfer learning and summarizes some lessons learned, and provides a massively multilingual diagnostic suite and fine-grained multi-dataset evaluation capabilities through an interactive public leaderboard to gain a better understanding of such models.

papers.title: Specializing Multilingual Language Models: An Empirical Study
papers.summary: These evaluations on part-of-speech tagging, universal dependency parsing, and named entity recognition in nine diverse low-resource languages uphold the viability of these approaches while raising new questions around how to optimally adapt multilingual models to low- resource settings.

papers.title: Translate & Fill: Improving Zero-Shot Multilingual Semantic Parsing with Synthetic Data
papers.summary: Experimental results on three multilingual semantic parsing datasets show that data augmentation with TaF reaches accuracies competitive with similar systems which rely on traditional alignment techniques.

papers.title: Interpreting BERT-based stance classification: a case study about the Brazilian COVID vaccination
papers.summary: This paper proposes a BERT-based stance classification model and an attention-based mechanism to identify the influential words for stance classification and uses these metrics to assess if words with high attention weights correspond to domain intrinsic properties and contribute to the correct classification of stances.

papers.title: reamtchka at SemEval-2022 Task 6: Investigating the effect of different loss functions for Sarcasm detection for unbalanced datasets
papers.summary: A voting classifier between either multiple different BERT-based models or machine learning models is proposed, as the final model in SemEval-2022 Task 6: Intended Sarcasm Detection in English and Arabic.

papers.title: Building Domain-specific Corpora from the Web: the Case of European Digital Service Infrastructures
papers.authors: Rik van Noord,Cristian García-Romero,M. Esplà-Gomis,Leopoldo Pla Sempere,Antonio Toral
papers.summary: This paper explores the feasibility of building an automatic classifier that allows to identify which segments in a generic corpus are relevant for a particular DSI, and uses pre-trained (multilingual) language models to perform the classification.

papers.title: How to encode arbitrarily complex morphology in word embeddings, no corpus needed
papers.summary: The word embeddings in this paper are explicitly designed to be both linguistically interpretable and fully capable of handling the broad variety found in the world’s diverse set of 7000 languages, regardless of corpus size or morphological characteristics.

papers.title: Vicomtech at LivingNER2022
papers.authors: Elena Zotova,Aitor García Pablos,Naiara Pérez,Pablo Turón,Montse Cuadros

papers.title: General-purpose, long-context autoregressive modeling with Perceiver AR
papers.authors: Curtis Hawthorne,Andrew Jaegle,Cătălina Cangea,Sebastian Borgeaud,Charlie Nash,Mateusz Malinowski,S. Dieleman,Oriol Vinyals,M. Botvinick,Ian Simon,Hannah R. Sheahan,Neil Zeghidour,Jean-Baptiste Alayrac,João Carreira,Jesse Engel
papers.summary: Perceiver AR is developed, an modality-agnostic architecture which uses cross-attention to map long-range inputs to a small number of latents while also maintaining end-to-end causal masking, enabling practical long-context density estimation without the need for hand-crafted sparsity patterns or memory mechanisms.

papers.title: Embarrassingly Simple Performance Prediction for Abductive Natural Language Inference
papers.summary: This work proposes a simple method for predicting the performance without actually fine-tuning the model of a natural language inference model, and shows that the accuracy of the cosine similarity approach correlates strongly with theuracy of the classification approach with a Pearson correlation coefficient of 0.65.

papers.title: Multilingual Abusiveness Identification on Code-Mixed Social Media Text
papers.summary: This work proposes an approach for abusiveness identiﬁcation on the multilingual Moj dataset which comprises of Indic languages and tackles the common challenges of non-English social media content and can be extended to other languages as well.

papers.title: KinyaBERT: a Morphology-aware Kinyarwanda Language Model
papers.summary: A simple yet effective two-tier BERT architecture that leverages a morphological analyzer and explicitly represents morphological compositionality is proposed, naming the proposed model architecture KinyaBERT.

papers.title: A Compact Pretraining Approach for Neural Language Models
papers.summary: This study shows that pretrained NLMs learn in-domain information more effectively and faster from a compact subset of the data that focuses on the key information in the domain.

papers.title: Transformers with Learnable Activation Functions
papers.summary: This paper investigates the effectiveness of using Rational Activation Function (RAF) that is a learnable activation function in the Transformer architecture and opens a new research direction for analyzing and interpreting pre-trained models according to the learned activation functions.

papers.title: J URASSIC -1: T ECHNICAL D ETAILS AND E VALUATION
papers.summary: Jurassic-1 is a pair of auto-regressive language models recently released by AI21 Labs, consisting of J1-Jumbo, a 178B-parameter model, and J1"-Large", and their architecture and training are described and their performance relative to GPT-3 is evaluated.

papers.title: PMI-Masking: Principled masking of correlated spans
papers.authors: Yoav Levine,Barak Lenz,Opher Lieber,Omri Abend,Kevin Leyton-Brown,Moshe Tennenholtz,Y. Shoham
papers.summary: PMI-Masking motivates, unifies, and improves upon prior more heuristic approaches that attempt to address the drawback of random uniform token masking, such as whole-word masks, entity/phrase masksing, and random-span masking.

papers.title: ERNIE-Gram: Pre-Training with Explicitly N-Gram Masked Language Modeling for Natural Language Understanding
papers.authors: Dongling Xiao,Yukun Li,Han Zhang,Yu Sun,Hao Tian,Hua Wu,Haifeng Wang
papers.summary: ERNIE-Gram is proposed, an explicitly n-gram masking method to enhance the integration of coarse-grained information into pre-training and outperforms previous pre- training models like XLNet and RoBERTa by a large margin, and achieves comparable results with state-of-the-art methods.

papers.title: Self-Teaching Machines to Read and Comprehend with Large-Scale Multi-Subject Question Answering Data
papers.summary: A self-teaching paradigm is proposed to better use the generated weakly-labeled MRC instances to improve a target MRC task and the effectiveness of this framework and the usefulness of large-scale subjectarea question-answering data for machine reading comprehension are demonstrated.

papers.title: Multi-view Subword Regularization
papers.summary: To take full advantage of different possible input segmentations, the proposed Multi-view Subword Regularization (MVR) method enforces the consistency of predictors between using inputs tokenized by the standard and probabilistic segmentations.

papers.title: Lattice-BERT: Leveraging Multi-Granularity Representations in Chinese Pre-trained Language Models
papers.authors: Yuxuan Lai,Yijia Liu,Yansong Feng,Songfang Huang,Dongyan Zhao
papers.summary: This work proposes a novel pre-training paradigm for Chinese — Lattice-BERT, which explicitly incorporates word representations along with characters, thus can model a sentence in a multi-granularity manner and achieves new state-of-the-art among base-size models on the CLUE benchmarks.

papers.title: SHUOWEN-JIEZI: Linguistically Informed Tokenizers For Chinese Language Model Pretraining
papers.authors: Chenglei Si,Zhengyan Zhang,Yingfa Chen,Fanchao Qi,Xiaozhi Wang,Zhiyuan Liu,Maosong Sun
papers.summary: It is found that SHUOWEN and JIEZI tokenizers can generally outperform conventional singlecharacter tokenizers, while Chinese word segmentation shows no benefit as a preprocessing step, and exhibit significantly better robustnesses on handling noisy texts.

papers.title: MVP-BERT: Multi-Vocab Pre-training for Chinese BERT
papers.summary: Experiments show that MVP training strategies improve PLMs’ downstream performances, especially it can improve the PLM’s performances on span-level tasks, and the AL-MVP outperforms the recent AMBERT (CITATION) after large-scale pre-training, and it is more robust against adversarial attacks.

papers.title: LICHEE: Improving Language Model Pre-training with Multi-grained Tokenization
papers.authors: Weidong Guo,Mingjun Zhao,Lusheng Zhang,Di Niu,Jinwen Luo,Zhenhua Liu,Zhenyang Li,J. Tang
papers.summary: This paper proposes a simple yet effective pretraining method named LICHEE to efficiently incorporate multi-grained information of input text that can be applied to various pretrained language models and improve their representation capability.

papers.title: Span Fine-tuning for Pre-trained Language Models
papers.summary: A novel span fine-tuning method for PrLMs is presented, which facilitates the span setting to be adaptively determined by specific downstream tasks during the fine- Tuning phase.

papers.title: CPT: A Pre-Trained Unbalanced Transformer for Both Chinese Language Understanding and Generation
papers.authors: Yunfan Shao,Zhichao Geng,Yitao Liu,Junqi Dai,Fei Yang,Li Zhe,H. Bao,Xipeng Qiu
papers.summary: The unbalanced Transformer saves the computational and storage cost, which makes CPT competitive and greatly accelerates the inference of text generation.

papers.title: Improving Constituent Representation with Hypertree Neural Networks
papers.summary: This paper aims to improve representations of constituent spans using a novel hypertree neural networks (HTNN) that is structured with constituency parse trees that incorporates both bottom-up and top-down compositional information.

papers.title: “Is Whole Word Masking Always Better for Chinese BERT?”: Probing on Chinese Grammatical Error Correction
papers.authors: Yong Dai,Linyang Li,Cong Zhou,Zhangyin Feng,Enbo Zhao,Xipeng Qiu,Pijian Li,Duyu Tang
papers.summary: Three Chinese BERT models with standard character-level masking (CLM), WWM, and a combination of CLM and WWM are trained and it is found that when one character needs to be inserted or replaced, the model trained with CLM performs the best.

papers.title: MarkBERT: Marking Word Boundaries Improves Chinese BERT
papers.authors: Linyang Li,Yong Dai,Duyu Tang,Zhangyin Feng,Cong Zhou,Xipeng Qiu,Zenglin Xu,Shuming Shi
papers.summary: A Chinese BERT model dubbed MarkBERT that uses word information and inserts boundary markers between contiguous words, which enables the model to handle any words in the same way, no matter they are OOV words or not is presented.

papers.title: Effectiveness of Fine-tuned BERT Model in Classification of Helpful and Unhelpful Online Customer Reviews
Clickbait Detection of Indonesian News Headlines using Fine-Tune Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT)
papers.venue: Inform : Jurnal Ilmiah Bidang Teknologi Informasi dan Komunikasi
papers.authors: Diyah Utami Kusumaning Putri,Dinar Nugroho Pratomo
papers.summary: This study fine-tunes the Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT) and uses the Indonesian news headlines dataset CLICK-ID to predict clickbait (BerT), and evaluation results indicate that all fine-tuned IndoBERT classifiers outperform all word-vectors-based machine learning classifiers in classifying Clickbait and non-clickbait IndonesianNews headlines.

papers.title: mmLayout: Multi-grained MultiModal Transformer for Document Understanding
papers.authors: Wenjin Wang,Zhengjie Huang,Bin Luo,Qianglong Chen,Qiming Peng,Yinxu Pan,Weichong Yin,Shi Feng,Yu Sun,Dianhai Yu,Yin Zhang
papers.summary: Experimental results on four tasks, including information extraction and document question answering, show that the proposed method can improve the performance of multimodal Transformers based on fine-grained elements and achieve better performance with fewer parameters.

papers.title: Look It Up: Bilingual Dictionaries Improve Neural Machine Translation
papers.summary: A new method for “attaching” dictionary definitions to rare words so that the network can learn the best way to use them and demonstrate provements of up to 1.8 BLEU using bilingual dictionaries.
